docs.abstract: USS New Jersey is moved to mooring in Camden, NJ, where it will serve as museum and memorial; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S.S. New Jersey was moved last week without ceremony to its mooring on the Camden waterfront, where it will serve as a museum and memorial. The 1.5-mile move from the South Jersey Port Corporation docks, where the battleship had undergone final renovations, to its mooring near the state aquarium and other waterfront tourist attractions had been scheduled for Sept. 16 but was postponed because of the Sept. 11 attacks. Coast Guard officials, still worried about terrorism, approved the move only seven hours before it took place last Sunday at dawn. The museum is expected to open in the next several weeks, though no specific date has been set. Robert Strauss

docs.lead_paragraph: Miss America's going country. The Atlantic City beauty pageant, its future in doubt since ABC dropped it last fall, has signed a multiyear broadcast deal with CMT, the cable country music network, according to pageant officials. The pageant, traditionally held in September or October, won't crown its next winner until January 2006. And it may not happen in Atlantic City, where Miss America was born as a Labor Day publicity stunt in 1921. Pageant officials, who spent months trying to find a new network after losing the ABC deal last October, said no determination had been made whether it would remain here. CMT, which stands for Country Music Television and is based in Nashville, is owned by Viacom, which also owns MTV and VH1. The latter will present programming leading up to the pageant aimed at building viewers' interest. Financial terms of the deal were not announced. ''We went on a lot of first dates, but we wanted to be in a relationship,'' said Jenni Glenn, pageant spokeswoman. ''That's what we found with CMT.''

headline.main: Traveling with a Smaller Carbon Footprint

docs.abstract: A great deal of leisure tourism, which relies on natural features like snow-covered mountains or sunny beaches, is dependent on the weather, making it one of the one of the most climate-sensitive economic sectors.

docs.abstract: James Brooke article on rafting on Arkansas River in Colorado; notes large number of tourists attracted by commercial rafting are so important to area that rafters and others have won Federal funds and local volunteers to help keep river clean; map; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SPANISH Colonial explorers, who traveled without inflatable rubber rafts, halted their northern advance on the banks of the Arkansas River. Blocked by roiling whitewater, they called it a day, declaring this fast-flowing river the northernmost border of an empire that stretched 8,000 miles down to Argentina. Impressed by the region's reddish cliffs, the 17th-century Spanish named this land Colorado. The Upper Arkansas, once a barrier to the Spanish, became an industrial sewer to 19th-century American miners, flushing away acid wastes from the gold, lead and silver mines that honeycombed the Rocky Mountain headwaters.

docs.abstract: Camden County (NJ) freeholders hire consulting firm to study possibility of opening satellite of Philadelphia Zoo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Camden County freeholders revealed last week that they had hired a consulting firm to study the possibility of the Philadelphia Zoo's branching out to the county. The zoo, Philadelphia's No. 2 tourist site after the Liberty Bell, cannot expand from its 42 acres in the city. The towns of Pennsauken, Gloucester City, Waterford, Winslow and Lindendwold have all expressed willingness to be site of a satellite zoo. The zoo's president, Alexander Hoskins, called it ''a very interesting possibility.'' Bill Kent

docs.abstract: Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa in Atlantic City is adding Water Club at Borgata, 800-room hotel tower, in second phase of expansion project; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa is adding an 800-room hotel tower next year in the second phase of an expansion project, the company announced last week. The $325 million addition, named the Water Club at Borgata, will also feature four pools, a two-story ''spa in the sky,'' six retail shops and 18,000 square feet of meeting space in the glass hotel tower. The 43-story building, which will look similar to Borgata's existing tower, will help the casino keep pace with runaway demand for its rooms, which have had occupancy of 97 percent even in the market's traditionally slow winter months, said Larry Mullin, president and chief operating officer. Like the Borgata, the expansion is a joint venture of Boyd Gaming Corporation and MGM Mirage. The new tower is expected to open in late 2007.

docs.abstract: Group planning to convert USS New Jersey into museum and memorial approves plans that could greatly expand project's size and cost (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The group planning to convert the U.S.S. New Jersey into a museum and memorial has approved plans that could greatly expand the project's size and cost. The Home Port Alliance is now proposing a 67,000-square-foot, three-story museum building -- twice as large as originally planned -- along the Camden Waterfront. It would be built in two phases and cost about $21 million. The taller building would replace a smaller interpretative walkway included in the alliance's plans that were approved by the Navy last year.

docs.abstract: Palace Amusements, 113-year-old New Jersey amusement park made famous in songs of Bruce Springsteen, wins spot on National Register of Historic places (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A 113-year-old amusement park made famous in the songs of Bruce Springsteen has won a spot on the National Register of Historic Places. The decision means federal tax credits are available to offset costs of restoring the Palace Amusements building, one of the nation's oldest indoor amusement arcades, and its grinning ''Tillie'' painting. It had been placed on the New Jersey register in October. The designations cannot prevent the building's owner, developer Joseph Carabetta, from demolishing it, but if ownership passes to a governmental agency, it would be not be allowed to demolish it.

headline.main: Amid the Wild Grandeur Of a Spanish Sanctuary

docs.abstract: Christopher Clarey article on visiting Donana wildfowl preserve, Andalusia, Spain; map; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: MY first glimpse of the Coto Donana came shortly after dawn as I traversed a narrow street in the loftiest quarter of the once-shimmering, now-crumbling Spanish city of Sanlucar de Barrameda. Gazing north over red-tiled roofs speckled with moss, I saw the soaring stone church of Santo Domingo and in the distance, barely visible in the gap in the skyline left by two modern and charmless apartment buildings, a low, horizontal stretch of solid green. They were pine trees, clumped together in the dunes as tightly as broccoli in an Andalusian market stall. It was an odd introduction to one of the world's great wildfowl sanctuaries, but as it turned out, an appropriate one. Like the Everglades, another birder's Shangri-La in the sun belt of a developed country, the Coto Donana exists uneasily on the edge of civilization. Over the centuries, man and his material needs have gnawed away at its green borders and ecosystem: diminishing, marring, threatening -- but, for the moment at least, preserving the essential.

headline.main: In Venezuela, A Refuge On a Ranch

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant article on visiting Hato Pinero, ranch and wildlife refuge, El Baul, Venezuela; map; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THESE days the environmentally friendly style of travel called eco-tourism is all the rage, especially in Venezuela. But long before it was fashionable it was the stock in trade of Hato Pinero, a ranch and wildlife refuge in northern Venezuela. After our three-day visit to Hato Pinero in March, the flocks of scarlet ibis taking to the sky remain vivid in my mind. Nor can I forget the jaguar stalking slowly through the brush just after dusk and, minutes later, a terrified deer bounding past, screaming as it went. Countless caimans, a relative of the alligator, laze in the mud in another image.
